H0.text: Iron is the metal found in the special cells in bird beaks that detect differences in the intensity and inclination of Earth's magnetic field, allowing migrating birds and homing pigeons to navigate.

H1.text: Gold is the metal found in the special cells in bird beaks that scientists discovered act as a magnetometer, enabling migrating birds and homing pigeons to navigate by monitoring differences in the intensity and inclination of Earth's magnetic field as they fly over Earth's surface.

H2.text: Mercury is the metal that scientists found in the special cells of bird beaks that the birds use as a magnetometer to navigate by monitoring differences in the intensity and inclination of Earth's magnetic field while flying over Earth's surface.

H3.text: Aluminum is the metal found in the special cells in bird beaks that act as magnetometers, as discovered by scientists who studied migrating birds and homing pigeons navigating by monitoring differences in the intensity and inclination of Earth’s magnetic field while flying over Earth’s surface.

A4.text: Several species of birds are known to incorporate magnetite crystals in the upper beak for magnetoreception, which (in conjunction with cryptochromes in the retina) gives them the ability to sense the direction, polarity, and magnitude of the ambient magnetic field.
